awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hydraulic Control and Mixing of the Deep Ocean Flow through the Samoan Passage
awd_abstract_narration:
The large-scale circulation of the ocean also known as the Meridional Overturning Circulation (MOC) comprises a series of shallow and deep water currents that transport mass, heat, carbon, and nutrients around the globe. The Samoan Passage, which carries the majority of the transport in its deep northward branch, is an important element of the Pacific Ocean circulation system. Recent observations supported by a previously funded NSF project have identified a previously unknown split of the flow between a deeper eastern channel and multiple shallower, western pathways within the Samoan Passage complex. Additional changes such as a warming and weakening of the flow through the passage have also been observed over the past twenty years, which supports the need for long-term observations.  This project will examine the dynamics of the flow through the Samoan Passage in detail using a combination of observations, theory and numerical models. Currently, there are no deep ocean monitoring system deployed in the Pacific MOC and this project has the potential to aid in the development of an observing system that can complement the one currently deployed in the Atlantic. Climate models predict a weakening of the global overturning circulation, which could be confirmed or refuted with these observing systems. The knowledge gained from the proposed work can likely be applied to similar deep passages and fracture zones around the world. Two early career scientists, summer undergraduates, a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher will gain valuable training in modern methods used in oceanography through this project.  Diverse outreach activities are planned to engage the public with the results and knowledge gained from this project through collaborations with a modern dance company, and the Birch Aquarium and a high school in San Diego.

Extensive measurements collected under previous NSF funding, including a combination of moored time series and deep towed measurements will be used to study hydraulic effects on the flow in the Samoan Passage. Strong turbulent mixing was observed as the flow passes through and over various constrictions and sills, thereby substantially altering its water mass characteristics. The recent measurements indicate hydraulic criticality of the flow through the Samoan Passage, at least at one major sill. The three specific objectives of this project include: investigating the influence of hydraulic processes on mixing and friction at various sills, studying hydraulic criticality and implications for transport and partition of the flow through and around the Samoan Passage, and informing an efficient monitoring strategy for the flow through the Samoan Passage. As a result of this project, hydraulic theory will be improved and observationally validated, making it applicable to dense overflows in other passages and to the flow in the multitude of fracture zones that are believed to be important drivers for abyssal upwelling.

por.por_cntn:
The Samoan passage is a gap in the deep South Pacific bathymetry, through which flows the majority of the bottom water supply to the North Pacific. As a "choke-point" in the deep flow, the Samoan Passage is a good place to observe the rate of northward-flowing bottom water (and, hence, the rate of ventilation of the deep North Pacific--about 20% of the global ocean volume--by waters which were recently in contact with the surface and therefore can carry atmospheric gases and heat to the long-term storage repository of the deep ocean). In addition, the accelerated flow through the Samoan Passage generates strong internal waves and turbulence, modifying the bottom water properties and making the Passage a natural fluid dynamics laboratory for the study of ocean mixing in stratified shear flows. The project reported on here is the analysis phase of an observational program that studied the bathymetry, transport, and mixing processes over the course of 3 research cruises and long- and short-term mooring measurements from 2012 to 2014.

Intellectual Merit: The observations revealed the complexity of the flow in the Samoan Passage, which is split into multiple channels with topographic sills (low points in the ridge like mountain passes) of different heights. The bulk of the densest water flows through the eastern channel, causing dramatic waves that break and stir the ambient fluid into the dense layer. Profiler measurements within these flows illustrate a new form of stratified turbulence with a greater efficiency of mixing (the ability to stir and smooth the distribution of tracers like chemicals and heat) than is found in most other parts of the ocean. Additionally, short-term moorings in different locations quite near each other showed very different relationships between currents and mixing, reinforcing the idea of steady patterns of flow steered by the shape of the sea floor and turbulence triggered by abrupt transitions in flow state.

Our long-term mooring observations revealed patterns of variability similar to those seen in a monitoring array 20 years earlier, with tidal fluctuations and an annual cycle of transport, as well as notable modulation at a period of about 30 days. The overall temperature of the dense flow had increased by about 0.02 degrees C and the long-term mean transport decreased by 10% from the earlier measurements, in agreement with other observations of abyssal warming and the weakening of bottom water formation around Antarctica. Both the similarities and the differences with the previous mooring measurements suggest that a long-term monitoring effort in the Samoan Passage is feasable and would be valuable in the effort to detect the impacts of high-latitude changes on they abyssal ocean.

The mathematical theories of rotating hydraulics have been used to understand and predict the flow through ocean choke points (including the Samoan Passage), and several extensions to these theories were developed during the project. One attempted to answer the question of why some of the dense water takes a long detour and flows past the Passage entrance and around the ridge. It was found that the relative amounts of drag and mixing along each route determine the fraction that takes each path, with one implication being that future changes in Antarctic Bottom Water supply could change this fraction and thereby change the rate of mixing and modification of the bottom water. A second theoretical development has explored the partition between the two main pathways within the Passage. This work also found that inflow density and transport changes could modify the partition and influence the mixing along each path.

Broader Impacts: The implications of the observational and theoretical findings are important for our goals of improving long-term forecasts of ocean circulation and heat and carbon storage as they relate to future climate. Current low-resolution climate models will never accurately reproduce the mixing processes in the Samoan Passage unless they are augmented with specific algorithms to describe them (as has been done for other choke points like the Denmark Strait in the North Atlantic) or are increased in resolution in the vicinity of the Passage. Just as importantly, we now know that our ability to detect the ocean's ongoing response to climate change can be enhanced by monitoring the Samoan Passage with a small number of moorings (a suitable complement to the sparse Deep Argo observations of upstream conditions that is currently underway in the South Pacific).

Additional broader impacts of the Samoan Passage project, though less weighty than the future of climate, included public presentations describing our work and inspiring young people at events in Samoa, San Diego, Hawaii, and Seattle, and the education of 2 Ph.D. graduate students and 2 postdocs, one of whom became a lead Principal Investigator over the course of our work together.
